"Bkav's history also lends its demonstration some credence. Nearly a decade ago, the company's researchers found that they could break the facial recognition of laptop makers including Lenovo, Toshiba, and Asus, with nothing more than two-dimensional images of a user's face. They presented those widely cited findings at the 2009 Black Hat security conference."

Dumb marketing ploy and also a stupid video. ¬†Face ID works well and keeps people out of your phone. Nobody is walking around with masks especially since they don't know whose iPhone they are stealing.

They are MORE likely to pull a fingerprint off the phone itself if it was left behind and create a rubber fingerprint mold (which has been shown to beat Touch ID very easily). ¬†Your face isn't left behind if you lose your phone.

So what are we proving here? ¬†That if you spent godless amounts of time and had free access to your own face to map and scale a mold of your face that you could unlock it with a mask? ¬†Stop feeding the clickbait.

The whole point of this is people should not presume a technology is hack proof. This isn't news in and of itself. Fingerprint scanners are even less reliable. What is news (or interesting) is how the team solved the problem (of bypassing the phone's security algorithms). 

On the surface, one would think the challenges with their approach make it unlikely to be a widespread threat. However, don't get comfortable with that thought. This underscores the fact it's possible to defeat the security with a low-cost but persistent effort. It won't take many generations of improvements for someone to find a similar hack method that works reliably and on a wider scale.

Known secrets (e.g. strong passwords), multi-factor authentication, and private-key tokens (e.g. RSA SecuriD) are still the best forms of protection. Anything more convenient will be less secure. Annoying, but true. How valuable is your data and privacy?
